name: Antibodies persist six months after second Moderna COVID-19 jab
introduction: Antibody activity remained high in all age groups beyond six months after the second dose of Modernaâs COVID-19 vaccine, according to research published in the New England Journal of Medicine.
content:
Antibody activity remained high in all age groups beyond six months after the second dose of Moderna’s (Nasdaq: MRNA) COVID-19 vaccine, according to research published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

Phase I results show that antibodies that were elicited by COVID-19 Vaccine Moderna persisted through six months after the second dose, as detected by three distinct serologic assays.

Ongoing studies are monitoring immune responses beyond six months as well as determining the effect of a booster dose to extend the duration and breadth of activity against emerging viral variants.

The lead author of the research summary, Nicole Doria-Rose, from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, wrote: “Our data show antibody persistence and thus support the use of this vaccine in addressing the Covid-19 pandemic.”

This research comes after data published in January showed that the two-dose regimen of the Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine at the 100µg dose is expected to be protective against emerging strains detected to date.

Meanwhile, the UK has begun the rollout of COVID-19 Vaccine Moderna. It is the third coronavirus jab to be rolled out in the country, following on from those produced by Pfizer (NYSE: PFE) and BioNTech (Nasdaq: BNTX), and AstraZeneca (LSE: AZN).

The UK has bought 17 million doses of COVID-19 Vaccine Moderna, and Phase III results suggest it has 100% efficacy against severe cases. Along with the Pfizer jab, it will be offered to British people aged under 30 years as an alternative to the AstraZeneca vaccine, which has been linked with cases of blood clots and so has a more marginal risk versus benefit profile in that age group.
